awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photon Funnels -- A Fundamentally New Concept for Concentrating Light
awd_abstract_narration:
Collecting and concentrating light is an essential process in any system utilizing optics.  Conventional lenses collect light and concentrate it to a spot, but the concentration spot moves as light rays strike at different angles or different positions.  As a result, sensors and detectors can lose energy as a source moves, and the efficiency of an optical devices is often limited by the angular acceptance of a lens or lens system.  In this project, a collaborative team at the University of Central Florida and the University of Texas at El Paso will explore a fundamentally new approach for concentrating light called "photon funnels," which is based on spatially engineered optical lattices.  Photon funnels will be designed to leverage an optical phenomenon called "self-collimation" to control how light propagates within an engineered lattice.  Using a collaborative approach that combines theory, simulation, fabrication, and optical testing, the team will develop fundamental knowledge that enables scientists and engineers to design photon funnels for a myriad of applications.  The benefits to society will include new technologies for imaging, optical detection and sensing, telecommunications and energy harvesting.  This interdisciplinary project will give research students cutting-edge training in optical engineering, physics, chemistry, materials science, and design and simulation.  Educational outreach activities integrated with the project will bring the excitement of the research to the broader community and will help to improve understanding of science and technology and encourage youth to pursue careers in related fields.
The research goals are to: 1) generate fundamental understanding of photon funnels and more generally self-collimating, spatially-variant lattices; 2) establish the fundamental performance-limits of photon funnels; 3) determine to what extent reciprocity limits their light collecting ability; and 4) create design-rules that engineers can use for their own applications.  Photon funnels are wavelength-scale aperiodic three-dimensional lattices in which the unit cells are spatially varied in orientation to direct light via self-collimation to a single concentration zone.  Because photon funnels work via self-collimation, they are not bound by Snell's law, so in principle they could collect and concentrate light incident at all positions, all angles, and all polarizations.  No existing technology offers this extraordinary capability.  Photon funnels and spatially-variant lattices are designed by spatially varying the structure of an optical lattices while preserving the self-collimating properties of the unit cells.  Spatially-variant lattices are fundamentally different from photonic crystals, metamaterials, and devices based on graded-index and transformation optics.  Spatially-variant lattices do not require exotic properties - like refractive index that is high, negative, or less than one - which makes spatially-variant lattices simpler to fabricate and inherently more manufacturable.  The project will transform how engineers design optical systems because they could set aside traditional ray optics in certain applications and use photon funnels to concentrate light.  Photon funnels and spatially-variant lattices offer tremendous potential because multiple functions can be integrated into a single device, including light collection and concentration, tight beam bending, wavelength separation, and control of polarization, phase, and power.

por.por_cntn:
In this project a collaborative team led by the University of Central Florida (UCF), with the University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP), generated new scientific understanding of an optical effect known as "self-collimation."  The team demonstrated how this knowledge can be applied by creating an entirely new class of micro-optical devices that concentrate and control light in novel ways.  New approaches are needed for directing the flow of light, concentrating it, and controlling its properties to enable next-generation advances in integrated photonics.  The team shared its discoveries through publicly available publications and presentations so that scientists and engineers can use self-collimation to achieve breakthroughs in optical computing, telecommunication, imaging, and sensing.

   INTELLECTUAL MERIT.  The self-collimation effect occurs in properly structured photonic crystals, which are two- and three-dimensional lattices that have periodicity comparable to the wavelength of light waves.  Light tends to spread out as it travels through air and other homogenous materials.  But in a self-collimating lattice, light's natural tendency to spread is suppressed, so the energy remains contained and directed.  Additionally, a lattice can be spatially varied in ways that preserve self-collimation while also concentrating the light, directing it along a preferred path, or altering its properties, like phase and polarization.

     The building blocks of self-collimating lattices are the repeated unit cell.  The team used electromagnetic simulations to study the electromagnetic properties of unit cells and lattices based upon them.  Selected lattices were fabricated using "multi-photon lithography" (MPL), which is an emerging method for laser-based nano-scale 3D printing.  The lattices were structurally and optically characterized and compared to simulations to develop design rules that can be used to optimize two- and three-dimensional self-collimating devices.  One, called a photon-funnel, was explored numerically and found to be effective for concentrating light in two dimensions, using certain high-index materials.  Another, called a lens-embedded photonic crystal, works like a lens to concentrate light, but it is not subject to certain limitations of conventional lenses that necessarily require multiple complex elements to achieve a strong focus.  The device can also work when fashioned from low-index materials like photopolymers, which makes it amenable to fabrication by MPL.  The team produced a wide range of lens-embedded photonic crystals to demonstrate function and open a path toward new applications in integrated photonics.  The team also collaborated with the group of Dr. Xiaoming Yu at UCF to explore how shaped laser beams could be used to fabricate complex 3D lattices more rapidly.

     BROADER IMPACTS.  The project generated twelve (12) peer-reviewed publications, thirteen (13) conference proceedings, three (3) contributed conference presentations, one (1) Ph.D. dissertation, and numerous invited talks presented at other academic institutions and national laboratories.  The project provided a rich context for interdisciplinary research-training at all levels -- involving undergraduates, graduates, post-doctoral associates, and even high school students -- across physics, optical engineering, materials science, and chemistry.  Team members who graduated went on to positions in manufacturing, research, and graduate study at prestigious institutions, including Intel, NASA, Lockheed Martin, Princeton, and others.  Discoveries from the work were brought to the general public through university teaching and external educational outreach events.  Students were also exposed to important non-technical forms of professional development that included ethics and responsible conduct in science and engineering.
